content: The Act is titled the "Furthering Access and Networks for Sports Act" or the "FANS Act." It defines the term "Sports Broadcasting Act of 1961" and includes amendments to it. The "Furthering Access and Networks for Sports Act" or the "FANS Act" includes amendments to the Sports Broadcasting Act of 1961, eliminating antitrust exemptions for sports blackouts during retransmission consent negotiations and local sports. The "FANS Act" amends the Sports Broadcasting Act of 1961 by eliminating antitrust exemptions for local sports blackouts and requiring leagues to make games available over the internet if not on television. It defines a "covered game" as one played in a club's home territory not available for private viewing through local TV or a multichannel video distributor. The term 'television broadcast station' is defined in the Communications Act of 1934, and 'Internet platform' is defined as a delivery mechanism using packet-switched protocol or any successor technology. SEC. 4. APPLICATION OF THE ANTITRUST LAWS TO PROFESSIONAL MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL. Section 27 of the Clayton Act (15 U.S.C. 26b) is amended to clarify the scope of conduct, acts, practices, and agreements related to employment of major league baseball players at the major league level. The amendments made by this Act shall take effect on the date of enactment and apply to contracts or agreements entered into or modified by a league subject to the Sports Broadcasting Act of 1961.
